dt: {bc}the ordinary language people use in speaking or writing

{bc}a literary medium distinguished from {d_link|poetry|poetry} especially by its greater irregularity and variety of {d_link|rhythm|rhythm} and its closer correspondence to the patterns of everyday speech
{bc}a dull or ordinary style, quality, or condition

quotes.t: In my own work I felt a need to hurry from climax as in film montage, or even in Joycean {qword}prose{/qword} with its strings of firecracker words …
Like many two-person writing teams, this one produces its share of three-legged {qword}prose{/qword} and redundancy.

… the esteemed critic James Wood reaches out to assure "the common reader" … that his {qword}prose{/qword} is as free as he can make it of what James Joyce termed "the true scholastic stink" of so much academic writing.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin {it}prosa{/it}, from feminine of {it}prorsus, prosus{/it}, straightforward, being in prose, contraction of {it}proversus{/it}, past participle of {it}provertere{/it} to turn forward, from {it}pro-{/it} forward + {it}vertere{/it} to turn {ma}{mat|pro-|}, {mat|worth|}{/ma}
shortdef: the ordinary language people use in speaking or writing
a literary medium distinguished from poetry especially by its greater irregularity and variety of rhythm and its closer correspondence to the patterns of everyday speech
a dull or ordinary style, quality, or condition

dt: {bc}to write or speak in a dull or ordinary manner

quotes.t: 'In the meantime,' said Traddles, coming back to his chair; 'and this is the end of my {qword}prosing{/qword} about myself, I get on as well as I can. I don't make much, but I don't spend much … '

shortdef: to write or speak in a dull or ordinary manner

dt: {bc}a freely rhythmical prose employing characteristic devices of verse (such as alliteration and assonance)

shortdef: a freely rhythmical prose employing characteristic devices of verse (such as alliteration and assonance)
